awd_titl_txt: An Astronomical Time Machine: Light Echoes from Historic Supernovae
awd_abstract_narration:
The investigator has discovered a way to study the 3-dimensional (3D) properties of a Supernova (SN), by observing SN light that only now reaches Earth, after bouncing off dust filaments. These light echoes provide a unique opportunity in astronomy: direct observation of the cause (the explosion) as well as the effect (the expanded remnant) of the same astronomical event.  Because the light echoes come from many directions around the supernovae, a 3D model of the event can be constructed.

The investigators plan public outreach talks, video summaries of their research and citizen science opportunities for the public.  The light echoes are novel events and are naturally great introductions to the history of astronomy, light travel time, SN explosion physics, and the advantage of spectroscopy compared to historical brightness measurements.  They are developing interactive learning materials available for introductory undergraduates. They have an exciting Citizen Science plan, which enables the public to learn the scientific process by identifying new light echoes in their observations.

The 3D model is valuable because modern theoretical work suggests that asymmetry may be a critical ingredient in the SN explosion mechanism. The investigators will expand their program to regularly observe 6 historical SN events.  They will observe with the NSF?s Blanco telescope, a large telescope, with a 4-meter aperture size. The 3-degree square field of view, combined with the fast 20 second readout of DECam, this the ideal telescope for this search. Since their targets are generally older than already detected supernovae, they expect the targets to be slightly fainter.  They will produce many 5 minute duration images a night.  They will use computers programmed for machine learning to identify echoes.  They will compare their machine learning results with Citizen Science analysis of the same images.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Tycho Brahe's observations of a supernova (SN) in 1572 challenged the teachings of Aristotle that the celestial realm was unchanging. We have discovered a way to see the same light that Tycho saw 440 years ago by observing SN light that only now reaches Earth after bouncing off dust filaments. These light echoes give us a unique opportunity in astronomy: direct observation of the cause (the explosion) as well as the effect (the expanded remnant) of the same astronomical event.

Light echoes are an astronomical time machine with which we can observe SNe that happened centuries ago with modern instrumentation. However, the observed light is not unadulterated, and in order to constrain the physical properties of SNe with light echoes, we need to model them. In his thesis paper “SpectAcLE: an Improved Method for Modeling Light Echo Spectra” (Partoush et al. 2024, ApJ, 970, 119), student Roee Partoush presents the ultimate guide/recipe on how to analyze and interpret light echo spectra. These tools will be the bases for the future analysis of light echoes.

We also discovered scattered light echoes in the 30 Doradus region in the Large Magellanic Cloud, very likely resulting from a supernova explosion. However, we find that none of the know supernova remnants can be the source of these light echoes, and therefore the light echoes must come from a yet undiscovered young supernova remnant. The most likely explanation for the lack of an associated remnant is that the remnant is located in a low density region and is therefore intrinsically faint (Johnson et al., in prep.). With the guidance derived from the light echoes, we now know where to look for this faint supernova remnant, which opens up a new way to find supernova remnants in regions with unusual low density.

The Great Eruption of Eta Carinae in the mid-1800s was a spectacular astronomical event visible to the naked eye, lasting more than 15 years and resulting in two beautiful bipolar outflows. Eta Carinae is the most massive star system in our Galaxy, and lost 20x the mass of the Sun in this eruption that has become the archetype for understanding unstable very massive stars and their eruptive mass loss. We have been monitoring the light echoes of Eta Car’s Great Eruption for nearly a decade, and with this data, we can now derive the full 15 year light curve of Eta Car’s Great Eruption (Rest et al., in prep)! With this light curve, we can constrain the physical mechanism that led to this eruption, and gather insight into these violent last stages of stellar evolution. PI Rest has given an Astronomy on Tap Halloween talk about light echoes and Eta Car in particular.  

The composition and structure of the interstellar medium (ISM) is critical to the evolution of galaxies and the formation of stars. The contents of the ISM provide the material for the formation of new stars and the launching of galactic winds. Knowledge of the ISM therefore informs our understanding of fundamental astrophysical processes. The Cas A SN, which exploded in ~1680, emitted a short pulse of very energetic radiation. This radiation heats up dust, which then thermally re-radiated light from the heated dust grains in the infrared (IR), known as IR echoes. We have obtained JWST NIRCam and NIRSpec images of these Cas A IR echoes, and these first NIRCam images have completely upended our view of the structure of the cold ISM! These echoes are like a CAT scan of the dust and ISM, and the only way to obtain a true 3D view of its structure. The echoes indicate dust sub-structures that are unlike anything we have ever seen in any ISM context, placing stringent constraints on ISM formation history. We will have a press conference at the upcoming AAS #245 presenting these results.
